Schools are open for a mix of in-person and remote learning.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211217142041/https://az.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-for-azerbaijan/

As of June 10, 2021, beaches, sport and health centers, places of religious worship, malls, and shopping centers are reopened, subject to COVID-related restrictions.  On September 2, 2021, the Cabinet of Ministers announced that foreigners may use their COVID-19 passport (or a document confirming full vaccination against COVID-19 or immunity to COVID-19) issued abroad to enter restaurants, hotels, large shopping centers, and other facilities that require a COVID-19 passport.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211217142041/https://az.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-for-azerbaijan/

In order to contain transmission of the virus, mass events and celebrations have been cancelled. We suggest you refrain from attending mass events, crowded venues and public gathering areas unless necessary.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211218155153/https://azerbaijan.travel/covid-19-en

In order to contain transmission of the virus, mass events and celebrations have been cancelled. We suggest you refrain from attending mass events, crowded venues and public gathering areas unless necessary.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211218155153/https://azerbaijan.travel/covid-19-en

Most public transportation, including the Baku Metro, reopened on May 31 for weekday operations, and resumed weekend operation beginning October 1, 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211217142041/https://az.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-for-azerbaijan/
Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211217142041/https://az.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-for-azerbaijan/

Citizens and residents of Russia, Turkey, the United States, Bahrain, the UAE, Great Britain, Israel, Hungary, Qatar, Germany, Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Ireland, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Canada, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Serbia, Singapore, Slovenia, Slovakia, Greece, China, Estonia, Finland, France, Hong Kong, Croatia, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Malaysia, Saudi Arabia, Japan, Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Brunei, South Korea, Chile, Ecuador, Cambodia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Kuwait, Kazakhstan, Maldives, Mexico, Morocco, Mongolia, Montenegro, Norway, Oman, Panama, Salvador, Uruguay and New Zealand are able to travel to Azerbaijan by air under the following conditions:  submission of an official document issued by the relevant country (COVID passport) on complete vaccination or recovery from COVID-19 for passengers over 18 years of age and a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours before the flight  submission of a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours before the flight for passengers aged from 1 to 18 years  Restrictions on travelling to and out of Azerbaijan by air or land are in force until the 1st of January 2022, except for cargo and charter flights.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211218155153/https://azerbaijan.travel/covid-19-en
The participants have also agreed to broaden awareness campaign.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211019005253/https://nk.gov.az/en/article/1233/

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Azerbaijan? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within one calendar day? Yes  COVID-19 testing is available in Baku. Individuals are responsible for the entire cost of COVID-19 tests and the cost is in the range of 100 AZN.  The labs listed on AZALâs website are accredited by the Management Union of Medical Territorial Units (TABIB) to offer COVID-19 tests.  Test results can be available by email or text message, depending on the procedures of each individual lab.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211217142041/https://az.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-for-azerbaijan/

Fines for Non-Compliance    Effective May 31, masks are not required outdoors, but remain obligatory inside and on public transportation.  Non-compliance with mask mandates can result in fines up to 600 AZN.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211217142041/https://az.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-for-azerbaijan/

Has the government of Azerbaijan approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes.  Are vaccines available in Azerbaijan for U.S. citizens to receive?  Yes.   Which vaccines are available in Azerbaijan?  According to a Ministry of Health announcement, the Pfizer vaccine is available to citizens 18 years and older at the Baku Health Center and the outpatient clinic of the Central Clinic Hospital.  SinoVacâs CoronaVac and Russiaâs Sputnik V vaccine are widely available.  Local media reports AstraZeneca vaccines are also available.  Please monitor local media for updates.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211217142041/https://az.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-for-azerbaijan/
If you are over 65, stay home    https://web.archive.org/web/20211218160319/https://koronavirusinfo.az/az

Current economic measures in place have been extended to December 31, 2021. The five socio-economic support measures that are extended until December 31, 2021 are as follows: Temporary unemployment due to force majeure for all sectors, The simple crisis gateway right for all sectors from a loss of 65% of turnover, A monthly bonus of 25 euros for beneficiaries of integration income, a GRAPA or an ARR Financial support for rail operators (people and freight) and Maintaining the VAT rate at 6% on hydroalcoholic gel and masks    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003171205/https://www.premier.be/fr/prolongation-ciblee-des-mesures-de-soutien-economique-jusquau-31-decembre-2021

The use of the facemask is now compulsory for all children above the age of 10, however, for education, communities decide whether or not to introduce compulsory masks for children under 12.    The use of the facemask is now required in the following circumstances: The Consultative Committee decided to generalise the wearing of masks, which will now be compulsory in the following situations:  in enclosed areas of public transport and organised collective transport;  for medical and non-medical professions;  in health care institutions;  in establishments and places where catering activities are organised;  in the context of events, both indoors and outdoors and regardless of the size of the event;  in shops and shopping centres;  in publicly accessible areas of companies, public administrations, etc;  in public buildings and courts;  in libraries, toy libraries and media libraries;  in publicly accessible areas of establishments in the cultural, festive, sports, recreational and event sectors;  in fitness centres;  in places of worship.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127092653/https://www.commissioner.brussels/en/updates-covid-19/item/888-covid-updates-17-11

Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210909174346/https://covid.aviq.be/sites/default/files/circulaires/2021-06/20210601-Directives-%C3%A9tablissements-pour-aines.pdf

In order to expand the immunity of the population and protect the most vulnerable people against the virus, the vaccination must take place over three phases, depending on the number of available doses.    GROUP 1a    In the first instance, the most vulnerable and exposed people will receive the vaccine.    Residents and employees in residential care centres and collective care institutions: since the outbreak of the pandemic, COVID-19 has hit the elderly particularly hard, principally those in residential care centres. They will be vaccinated first, then the corresponding staff (including volunteers), followed by collective care institutions.  Medical personnel from first-line care and hospitals: they are in close contact with COVID-19 patients every day. To protect them, they will be prioritised for vaccination.  The other staff in hospitals and healthcare centres will be vaccinated, including organisations which work in prevention activities, such as vaccination centres and cancer screening centres, Child and Family and ONE.  GROUP 1b : vulnerable people without acute medical issues, but at high risk    In this phase, priority was given to people outside hospitals, who are at the highest risk. It concerns the following groups:    People over the age of 65 : people older than 65 will be a priority in this phase. We have started with the oldest people and then go down through the age groups.  Patients aged 18 to 64 with: â¢ chronic kidney disease present for at least 3 months â¢ chronic liver disease present for at least 6 months â¢ haematological cancers (eg leukemia) â¢ down syndrome â¢ transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) â¢ impaired immune system i.e. suffer from an immunodeficiency or take immunosuppressants â¢ active HIV/AIDS â¢ Some rare diseases belonging to the official lists of rare diseases  Patients aged 45 to 64 with: â¢ Chronic severe respiratory disease â¢ chronic cardiovascular disease â¢ obesity (obesity) with BMI = 30 â¢ diabetes type I and II â¢ chronic nervous system disorders â¢ dementia â¢ cancer (tumours) no more than 5 years ago â¢ elevated blood pressure at least 14O mmHG systolic or at least 90 mmHg diastolic    Pregnant women: to be vaccinated as a priority, they must contact their regular GP. Only their GP can add them. Pregnant women who do not yet have a GP should consult one.    Critical functions: In this phase people who fulfill an essential function will be vaccinated. This concerns a limited group of public order services with high-risk contacts (i.e. the intervention units of the police).    penitentiary officers    (para)olympic athletes and the Red Devils who participated in the European Championship    People aged 12 to 18 with the following risk factors (since June 2021, see below for procedure): *chronic kidney disease for at least 3 months *chronic liver disease for at least 6 months *haematological cancers (eg leukemia) *down syndrome *transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) *impaired immune system i.e. suffering from immunodeficiency or use of immunosuppressants *active HIV/AIDS *Some rare disorders (see Orphanet list: https://www.orpha.net/consor/cgi-bin/Disease_Search_List.php?lng=EN).    GROUP 2 - broader population from 12 years old    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212151840/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/vaccination/
No change in policy    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216155340/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/vaccination/
No change in policy    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216155340/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/vaccination/

An additional dose of the vaccine is now recommended for the whole population. Following the approval recieved from the European Medicines Agency,  the Consultative Committee has asked that the Supreme Health Council and the Advisory Committee on Bioethics give their opinion on a date to start vaccinating 5- to 11-year-olds on a voluntary basis.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127094244/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/news/occ-2611/

GROUP 1a    In the first instance, the most vulnerable and exposed people will receive the vaccine.    Residents and employees in residential care centres and collective care institutions: since the outbreak of the pandemic, COVID-19 has hit the elderly particularly hard, principally those in residential care centres. They will be vaccinated first, then the corresponding staff (including volunteers), followed by collective care institutions.  Medical personnel from first-line care and hospitals: they are in close contact with COVID-19 patients every day. To protect them, they will be prioritised for vaccination.  The other staff in hospitals and healthcare centres will be vaccinated, including organisations which work in prevention activities, such as vaccination centres and cancer screening centres, Child and Family and ONE.  GROUP 1b : vulnerable people without acute medical issues, but at high risk    In this phase, priority was given to people outside hospitals, who are at the highest risk. It concerns the following groups:    People over the age of 65 : people older than 65 will be a priority in this phase. We have started with the oldest people and then go down through the age groups.  Patients aged 18 to 64 with: â¢ chronic kidney disease present for at least 3 months â¢ chronic liver disease present for at least 6 months â¢ haematological cancers (eg leukemia) â¢ down syndrome â¢ transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) â¢ impaired immune system i.e. suffer from an immunodeficiency or take immunosuppressants â¢ active HIV/AIDS â¢ Some rare diseases belonging to the official lists of rare diseases  Patients aged 45 to 64 with: â¢ Chronic severe respiratory disease â¢ chronic cardiovascular disease â¢ obesity (obesity) with BMI = 30 â¢ diabetes type I and II â¢ chronic nervous system disorders â¢ dementia â¢ cancer (tumours) no more than 5 years ago â¢ elevated blood pressure at least 14O mmHG systolic or at least 90 mmHg diastolic    Pregnant women: to be vaccinated as a priority, they must contact their regular GP. Only their GP can add them. Pregnant women who do not yet have a GP should consult one.    Critical functions: In this phase people who fulfill an essential function will be vaccinated. This concerns a limited group of public order services with high-risk contacts (i.e. the intervention units of the police).    penitentiary officers    (para)olympic athletes and the Red Devils who participated in the European Championship    People aged 12 to 18 with the following risk factors (since June 2021, see below for procedure): *chronic kidney disease for at least 3 months *chronic liver disease for at least 6 months *haematological cancers (eg leukemia) *down syndrome *transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) *impaired immune system i.e. suffering from immunodeficiency or use of immunosuppressants *active HIV/AIDS *Some rare disorders (see Orphanet list: https://www.orpha.net/consor/cgi-bin/Disease_Search_List.php?lng=EN). Medical personnel from first-line care and hospitals: they are in close contact with COVID-19 patients every day. To protect them, they will be prioritised for vaccination.  The other staff in hospitals and healthcare centres will be vaccinated, including organisations which work in prevention activities, such as vaccination centres and cancer screening centres, Child and Family and ONE.  GROUP 1b : vulnerable people without acute medical issues, but at high risk    In this phase, priority was given to people outside hospitals, who are at the highest risk. It concerns the following groups:    People over the age of 65 : people older than 65 will be a priority in this phase. We have started with the oldest people and then go down through the age groups.  Patients aged 18 to 64 with: â¢ chronic kidney disease present for at least 3 months â¢ chronic liver disease present for at least 6 months â¢ haematological cancers (eg leukemia) â¢ down syndrome â¢ transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) â¢ impaired immune system i.e. suffer from an immunodeficiency or take immunosuppressants â¢ active HIV/AIDS â¢ Some rare diseases belonging to the official lists of rare diseases  Patients aged 45 to 64 with: â¢ Chronic severe respiratory disease â¢ chronic cardiovascular disease â¢ obesity (obesity) with BMI = 30 â¢ diabetes type I and II â¢ chronic nervous system disorders â¢ dementia â¢ cancer (tumours) no more than 5 years ago â¢ elevated blood pressure at least 14O mmHG systolic or at least 90 mmHg diastolic    Pregnant women: to be vaccinated as a priority, they must contact their regular GP. Only their GP can add them. Pregnant women who do not yet have a GP should consult one.    Critical functions: In this phase people who fulfill an essential function will be vaccinated. This concerns a limited group of public order services with high-risk contacts (i.e. the intervention units of the police).    penitentiary officers    (para)olympic athletes and the Red Devils who participated in the European Championship    People aged 12 to 18 with the following risk factors (since June 2021, see below for procedure): *chronic kidney disease for at least 3 months *chronic liver disease for at least 6 months *haematological cancers (eg leukemia) *down syndrome *transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) *impaired immune system i.e. suffering from immunodeficiency or use of immunosuppressants *active HIV/AIDS *Some rare disorders (see Orphanet list: https://www.orpha.net/consor/cgi-bin/Disease_Search_List.php?lng=EN).    GROUP 2 - broader population from 12 years old    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211115220254/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/vaccination/

An additional dose of the vaccine is now recommended for the whole population. Following the approval recieved from the European Medicines Agency,  the Consultative Committee has asked that the Supreme Health Council and the Advisory Committee on Bioethics give their opinion on a date to start vaccinating 5- to 11-year-olds on a voluntary basis.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127094244/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/news/occ-2611/

In order to expand the immunity of the population and protect the most vulnerable people against the virus, the vaccination must take place over three phases, depending on the number of available doses.    GROUP 1a    In the first instance, the most vulnerable and exposed people will receive the vaccine.    Residents and employees in residential care centres and collective care institutions: since the outbreak of the pandemic, COVID-19 has hit the elderly particularly hard, principally those in residential care centres. They will be vaccinated first, then the corresponding staff (including volunteers), followed by collective care institutions.  Medical personnel from first-line care and hospitals: they are in close contact with COVID-19 patients every day. To protect them, they will be prioritised for vaccination.  The other staff in hospitals and healthcare centres will be vaccinated, including organisations which work in prevention activities, such as vaccination centres and cancer screening centres, Child and Family and ONE.  GROUP 1b : vulnerable people without acute medical issues, but at high risk    In this phase, priority was given to people outside hospitals, who are at the highest risk. It concerns the following groups:    People over the age of 65 : people older than 65 will be a priority in this phase. We have started with the oldest people and then go down through the age groups.  Patients aged 18 to 64 with: â¢ chronic kidney disease present for at least 3 months â¢ chronic liver disease present for at least 6 months â¢ haematological cancers (eg leukemia) â¢ down syndrome â¢ transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) â¢ impaired immune system i.e. suffer from an immunodeficiency or take immunosuppressants â¢ active HIV/AIDS â¢ Some rare diseases belonging to the official lists of rare diseases  Patients aged 45 to 64 with: â¢ Chronic severe respiratory disease â¢ chronic cardiovascular disease â¢ obesity (obesity) with BMI = 30 â¢ diabetes type I and II â¢ chronic nervous system disorders â¢ dementia â¢ cancer (tumours) no more than 5 years ago â¢ elevated blood pressure at least 14O mmHG systolic or at least 90 mmHg diastolic    Pregnant women: to be vaccinated as a priority, they must contact their regular GP. Only their GP can add them. Pregnant women who do not yet have a GP should consult one.    Critical functions: In this phase people who fulfill an essential function will be vaccinated. This concerns a limited group of public order services with high-risk contacts (i.e. the intervention units of the police).    penitentiary officers    (para)olympic athletes and the Red Devils who participated in the European Championship    People aged 12 to 18 with the following risk factors (since June 2021, see below for procedure): *chronic kidney disease for at least 3 months *chronic liver disease for at least 6 months *haematological cancers (eg leukemia) *down syndrome *transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) *impaired immune system i.e. suffering from immunodeficiency or use of immunosuppressants *active HIV/AIDS *Some rare disorders (see Orphanet list: https://www.orpha.net/consor/cgi-bin/Disease_Search_List.php?lng=EN). Group classes for adults in language centers, educational centers, and other training centers and schools are suspended. Conducting face-to-face group classes for children in language centers, educational centers, personal development support centers and other training centers and schools is allowed provided at a physical distance of at least 1.5 m and not more than 5 people in a room, wearing protective face masks, hand hygiene, regular airing every hour and disinfection. Restrictions do not apply to special education support centers. The present learning process in the higher schools is terminated. Learning for students from 1-12th grade is suspended. Students from 5-12tth grade must wear a mask in class.   https://archive.vn/QUcwF

The holding of congress-conference events, seminars, symposiums, trainings, competitions, exams and other group events of this nature is suspended. Teambuilding and other organized group events of this nature in work teams are suspended. Employers and recruitment bodies to organize the work process of employees in remote form (distance work / home work), where possible, allowing the presence of at most 50% of the staff. Working hours are between 7.30 am and 10.00 am. 50% of staff must be remote unless impossible. Essential workers but have valid vaccination, illness, or testing documents.   https://archive.vn/QUcwF

Employers and appointment bodies in all administrations within the meaning of Art. 1 of the Administration Act organize the work process of the employees, as: (a) establish working hours with variable limits and the start of the working day between 7.30 am and 10.00 am, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work; (b) assign remote work to at least 50% of staff, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work.  Employers in hospitals, complex oncology centers, dialysis centers, hospices and nursing homes organize the work process by admitting to work only employees with valid documents for vaccination, illness or testing within the meaning of this order.   Visits to fitness centers, sports halls and clubs, swimming pools and complexes, balneotherapy (medical SPA) centers, SPA centers, wellness centers and thalassotherapy centers are suspended. Visits to gambling halls, casinos and food and entertainment establishments within the meaning of Art. 124 of the Tourism Act, including those to the places of accommodation. Visits to shopping malls, shops with a net retail area of ??over 300 square meters, bazaars and indoor exhibitions shall be suspended. Exceptions are allowed for shops offering mainly groceries, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet shops, banks, postal and courier service providers, insurers, payment service providers and telecommunications operators' offices, whether they are stand-alone or located in a shopping center type Mall. An exception is allowed for medical establishments and vaccination points located on the territory of shopping centers.     http://web.archive.org/web/20211219181539/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Exercise a high degree of caution when entering Bulgaria. Avoid non-essential travel in or out of the country due to the omicron variant. The EU follows the light system with different testing, quarantine, and vaccination policies.   https://archive.vn/zAoJL

Green & Orange zone - persons are admitted to the territory of the country upon presentation of a valid EU digital COVID certificate for vaccination, disease or testing or a similar document containing the same data as the EU digital COVID certificate. Persons who do not present a document shall be placed under quarantine for 10 days in the home or other place of accommodation in which the person has indicated that he will reside, with a prescription issued by the director of the relevant regional health inspectorate or authorized by his deputy director. The quarantined person may carry out a polymerase chain reaction test to detect COVID-19 or a rapid antigen test of those listed in Annex ? 2 not earlier than 72 hours of arrival in the country. In case of a negative result of the conducted research, the quarantine of the person shall be considered terminated from the day following the registration of the result in the National Information System for Combating COVID-19.  Red zone - on the territory of the country are allowed only persons who meet one of the exceptions. The persons are admitted to the territory of the country upon presentation of a valid EU digital COVID certificate for vaccination or illness or similar document, or a negative result from a polymerase chain reaction test for COVID-19 conducted up to 72 hours before entry into the country, certified by a valid EU digital COVID certificate for research or a similar document containing the same data as the EU digital COVID certificate for research.   Persons arriving from the following countries of the red zone are not allowed on the territory of the country: the Republic of Mozambique, the Republic of Botswana, the Republic of South Africa, Lesotho, Eswatini, the Republic of Namibia and the Republic of Zimbabwe, except for persons who are Bulgarian citizens and persons with status of permanent, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria and the members of their families.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211219181539/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Schools are opening with epidmiological measurements     Basic principles: wearing masks for students (children aged 6 to 11 should wear a mask  outside the classroom, not necessarily during class; while older children should wear a mask for  teaching time), wearing masks for teaching and other staff, maintaining adequate physical  distance, maintaining hand hygiene.  Vaccination against COVID-19 teaching staff and students depending on the recommended age for  Vaccination, as well as their household members, are key strategies to help schools  operate at full capacity.  Students, teachers and other staff should stay home if they or any of their household members have  symptoms associated with COVID-19 (main symptoms are fever, cough,  loss of sense of smell / taste, weakness; other symptoms: pain, headache, conjunctivitis, diarrhea,  skin rash).  https://web.archive.org/web/20211201200607/https://www.zzjzfbih.ba/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/Preporuke-za-%C5%A1kole-u-kontekstu-COVID-19_2021_22.pdf

COVID-19 specific guidelines  - Detect and monitor the occurrence of COVID-19 cases related to public gatherings.  It is recommended that there is a list of guests, a list of visitors. It is necessary to have access control to  an event. Depending on the epidemiological situation, introduce screening of visitors for COVID-19 symptoms  illness upon entering the event.  - Apply appropriate measures to prevent the spread of the virus.  All measures prescribed by the competent authorities, such as: wearing masks over the mouth and nose, maintenance  physical distances between persons of 1.5-2m at all times, avoiding direct close contact  (handling, hugging, kissing), ensuring adequate hygienic conditions (toilets, washing and disinfection)  hand).  - Inform visitors about public health measures specific to prevent the spread. Prepare  posters, leaflets and other ways of informing about COVID-19.  - Plan to monitor the implementation of these measures, operational team / wardens / police.  - Plan decisions in case of deterioration of the epidemiological situation. In that case, it might be  necessary to significantly reduce the number of visitors and guests, or even cancel the event.  - Have a communication plan with the competent health institutions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211216054444/https://www.zzjzfbih.ba/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Preporuke-za-javna-okupljanja.pdf
https://web.archive.org/web/20211221140356/https://www.zzjzfbih.ba/preporuke-covid-19/

Limit the number of guests to the smallest possible number, in accordance with currently valid orders  competent crisis headquarters - up to 50 people indoors. Attendance only is recommended  celebrants and necessary guests (eg graduates) and the necessary staff, with as few as possible  guests (eg family members). The presence of people from abroad is not recommended, nor is it  persons over 65 years of age.  - Officials with signs of respiratory disease (fever, cough,  difficulty breathing) should not attend the event and should consult their doctor.  - Keep records of present guests and guests, and record the seating schedule. This will be  useful to healthcare professionals in the event of an outbreak of COVID-19 after an event, a  who were present at the celebration. This record should contain basic information and contact  data of persons present at the celebration.  - It is recommended that all celebrations be organized outdoors whenever possible, with  ensuring a minimum distance between persons according to previous recommendations (1-2m).  If the celebration is held indoors, the number of guests must also be according to orders  competent, while ensuring the recommended distance between persons. Indoors  it is especially important to ensure good ventilation with outside air as well as other conditions recommended  for catering facilities.  - It is recommended that the guests sit at the tables and that there are no activities during the celebration  which comes into close contact, except between members of the same household, such as dancing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203152743/https://www.zzjzfbih.ba/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Preporuke-proslave-1.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211221140356/https://www.zzjzfbih.ba/preporuke-covid-19/

Entry and Exit Requirements:  Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? Yes  U.S. citizens wishing to enter BiH must have one of the following: a negative COVID-19 test (PCR or antigen) not older than 48 hours if coming from Europe and not older than 72 hours if arriving from other countries (including the United States); or a COVID-19 vaccination certificate showing full vaccination completed 10 days prior to arrival; or a doctorâs certificate of COVID-19 recovery in the period 10 to 180 days prior to arrival.  Children until the age of seven, accompanied by a parent who meets the above conditions may enter without a COVID-19 test or certificate.  Foreign nationals who are permanently or temporarily resident in BiH may enter without a COVID-19 test or certificate if returning from Croatia, Montenegro or Serbia with stays in those countries for less than 48 hours.  Citizens of Croatia, Montenegro or Serbia may enter without a COVID-19 test or certificate when coming directly from those countries.  The BiH Border Police website has detailed information on entry and exit requirements and exceptions. For the most up-to-date information, visit their website or contact them directly by calling their Operations Center at +387 33 755 300.  Requirements and restrictions may change without advance notice.  Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? No.  See above.  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? No  Nations bordering BiH also maintain border restrictions. For questions regarding those, please visit the following websites:    https://web.archive.org/web/20211221134628/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Not a major changes
not a major changes

COVID-19 Testing:  Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in BiH? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Private and public clinics throughout BiH perform PCR and serological COVID-19 tests. Payment is due in full at the time of the test and current prices are roughly 100 convertible marks (km) for PCR and 40km for antigen.  Turnaround of results and availability of testing appointments vary based on the city yet clinics in most large cities have testing options daily and return results within 24 hours.  A list of clinics known to provide COVID-19 testing in BiH can be found on our website here  Public Health Centers (Dom Zdravlja) test symptomatic individuals regardless of nationality, free of charge. To arrange a test, contact your cantonâs health center for additional guidance.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211221134628/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Generally requred including public spaces and public transits   https://web.archive.org/web/20211221134628/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211221140356/https://www.zzjzfbih.ba/preporuke-covid-19/

COVID-19 Vaccine Information:  Has the government of BiH approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Yes  Are vaccines available in BiH for U.S. citizens to receive? No  Eligible individuals (residents and/or persons with local health insurance) can sign up following instructions from their locality.  Sarajevo Canton has announced that all residents of the Canton can receive the vaccine at Health Centers (Dom zdravlja) regardless of whether they have local health insurance. Check with them directly for more information.  Click here for Canton Sarajevoâs vaccination registration page    (Accessible only from local IP addresses.)  Which vaccines are available in BiH? Pfizer, AstraZeneca, Sputnik V, Sinopharm, Moderna  Follow official local sources (also see Local Resources, below) for announcements about vaccines in your area.  Visit the FDAâs website to learn more about FDA-approved vaccines in the United States.  The United States Government does not plan to provide COVID-19 vaccinations to private U.S. citizens overseas. Please follow host country developments and guidelines for COVID-19 vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211221134628/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No evidence of policy change. Schools in Switzerland function as normal. Only some protective measures such as mask-wearing apply. Working from home remains recommended in all sectors possible. It is up to employers determining whether or not a COVID certificate is necessary to work. This is what can be read on its website:     "Working from home is urgently recommended in all areas where it is possible to work from home without disproportionate effort."    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211130195203/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

The Swiss government and health authorities have heightened the restrictions on in-person working. Working from home is now mandatory in Switzerland.  This is what can be read on the government's website:    "Working from home: Working from home is mandatory. Employers must take appropriate organisational and technical measures to enable homeworking."    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211221150320/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

A COVID certificate is still needed to access public places such as discos, clubs, concerts, or sporting events.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211127004559/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

Access to indoor and outdoor events is limited to people holding a Covid certificate. There only exist limited exceptions, such as religious ceremonies or funerals.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211130195203/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

This is what can be read on governmental sources:    "Access to indoor events for people aged 16 and over is basically restricted to people who are vaccinated or recovered". Only certain events, such as religious ceremonies or funerals are exempt from this restriction.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211221150320/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

No evidence of policy change:  "The number of people allowed to attend events among friends and family (for example gatherings and parties) that are not held in publicly accessible establishments and businesses is limited. The numbers include children.      Rule indoors: A maximum of 30 people is allowed.  Rule outdoors: A maximum of 50 people is allowed."    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211127004559/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

This is what can be read on the government's website:    "The number of people allowed to attend events among friends and family (for example gatherings and parties) that are not held in publicly accessible establishments and businesses is limited. The numbers include children.      Rule indoors without certificate: A maximum of 30 people is allowed.    If more than 10 people are present, it is recommended to limit access to people with a certificate.    Rule outdoors: A maximum of 50 people is allowed."    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211130195203/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

The Swiss government and health authorities have intensified restrictions on gatherings, especially in settings where there's an unvaccinated individual. This is what can be read on the government's website:    "The number of people allowed to attend events among friends and family (for example gatherings and parties) that are not held in publicly accessible establishments is limited. The numbers include children.      Rule indoors without certificate: A maximum of 30 people is allowed if everyone is vaccinated or recovered. As soon as one person is present who is not vaccinated or recovered and is aged over 16, only up to 10 people may gather.    Rule outdoors: A maximum of 50 people is allowed."    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211221150320/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

Although the Swiss government was already restricting travel from certain high-risk destinations, it has further tightened travel limitations starting on November 26th. Specifically, it has intensified restrictions for travelers coming from South African countries amid concerns about the new variant. South Africa, Lesotho, Namibia, Botswana, and other countries where the new strain has been detected have been added to this list.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211125023337/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html

A travel ban remains in place for foreign travelers from several countries, especially from outside the Schengen Area. In addition, there are some testing requirements for both the vaccinated and the unvaccinated. The vaccinated, for instance, need to provide an entry form and present a negative test. The unvaccinated have to provide a second test after 4-7 days since arrival. More information on the banned countries and entry requirements can be found in the links below:    http://web.archive.org/web/20211221151757/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20211221151815/https://www.sem.admin.ch/sem/en/home/sem/aktuell/faq-einreiseverweigerung.html

Target group 1: People at especially high risk, from age 16  Target group 2: Healthcare professionals with patient contact/carers for people at especially high risk  Target group 3: Close contacts (household members or relatives providing care) of people at especially high risk, particularly people with a weakened immune system, from age 16  Target group 4: People in communal facilities with an increased risk of infection and outbreaks (for example homes for the people with disabilities), age 16 to 64  Target group 5: Adults (age 16 to 64) who do not fall into target groups 1 to 4  Target group 6: Adolescents (age 12 to 15) who wish to be vaccinated  http://web.archive.org/web/20210709105625/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html    Especially high risk:  Older people  Pregnant women  Adults with Trisomy 21  Adults with certain forms of chronic conditions

There's evidence that people in all age groups are getting the vaccine in Switzerland. For instance, 79% of individuals between 50 and 59 years old have been fully vaccinated. This statistic is 75% for those between 40-49, and 68% for those between 20-29.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211220085326/https://www.covid19.admin.ch/en/vaccination/persons

The costs of a COVID-19 vaccination are covered by mandatory health insurance.   The vaccination is thus free of charge for people with mandatory health insurance in Switzerland.   Also free of charge if:  You live in Switzerland and, for example, work for a diplomatic or consular representation or an international organisation.  You live in Switzerland as an employee on secondment, a student or pensioner.  You are a cross-border commuter and are exposed to a risk of infection at work (e.g. healthcare personnel with patient contact or care staff in retirement and care homes).  For these groups the costs of the COVID-19 vaccination will be covered by the Swiss federal government.    The costs will not be covered if you are not in one of the groups of people described above.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210424202000/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html#-134524438

Schools have started full-time teaching, subject to compliance with hygiene measures.   Pupil testing is again taking place throughout the Czech Republic. Testing will take place on 6th December  It will then be repeated every Monday (or the first day of the new school week). This compensation applies to cases where employees are ordered to quarantine or to be isolated due to COVID-19. The amount of the support is set at 80% of eligible costs (compensation of wages paid to employees + the corresponding amount of statutory contributions), but a maximum of CZK 39,000 per employee and month. Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately.    Pupils from 1st grade onwards and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to be tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 months.    Two weekly test are recommended in municipalities and parishes with high infection rates.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127102306/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately. Pupils from 1st grade onwards and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to be tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 months. Two weekly test are recommended in municipalities and parishes with high infection rates.    Corona passport is required at educational institutions such as universities, youth education and language schools    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202160355/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately. Pupils from 1st grade onwards and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to be tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 months. Two weekly test are recommended in municipalities and parishes with high infection rates.    Corona passport is required at educational institutions such as universities, youth education and language schools    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212155303/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

Children in primary school will be sent home from Wednesday 15 December 2021 until (and including) Tuesday 4 January 2022. Pupils in boarding schools and independent vocational schools will be sent home from Sunday 19 December 2021 to (and including) Friday 7 January 2021.    While in school, however, Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately. Pupils from 1st grade onwards and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to get tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 6 months. Two weekly tests are recommended in municipalities and parishes with high infection rates.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216151102/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

A COVID certificate or similar document that proves vaccination, previous infection with COVID or  a recent negative test is needed for entry into certain restaurants, nightlife and some culture venues.    People who attend work physically are advised not to go their workplace if they  experience COVID 19 symptoms and to get tested.       Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127102306/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

From 26 November 2021 employees in the state and the regions are required to present coronapas. Physical attendance at the workplace is the rule unless otherwise agreed with the employer.  Corona passes are needed when attending a conference, unless the organizer ensures that there are 100 or fewer spectators / participants indoors and 1,000 or fewer spectators / participants outdoors. There are special recommendations for testing of staff in geriatric care as well as staff in primary schools who have not been vaccinated or previously infected (within the last 6 months).    At discos and nightclubs you must present corona passport/COVID Certificate or similar. Face masks are not required.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202160355/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

It is adviced to work at home extensively in both public and private workplaces and that meetings, seminars etc. are held virtually. It is adviced to cancel major social events at workplaces, including Christmas lunches. Municipal employers can require their employees to present a corona passport/COVID certificate. Employers may also, under certain conditions, require employees to be tested for corona and disclose the result of the test. However, employers must be able to objectively justify that a test is necessary to limit the spread of infection with COVID-19. Employees in the state and the regions will be required to present a corona passport/COVID certificate. A corona passport/COVID certificate when attending a conference, unless the organizer ensures that there are 100 or fewer spectators/participants indoors and 1,000 or fewer spectators/participants outdoors.    Discos, nightclubs and partybusses are closed, while bars must close at midnight.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212155303/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

It is adviced to work at home extensively in both public and private workplaces and that meetings, seminars etc. are held virtually.  It is adviced to cancel major social events at workplaces, including Christmas lunches. Discos and nightclubs are closed. Bars must close at midnight. 1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents coming in EU/Schengen, OECD countries or  COVID-19 risk countries, can enter Denmark without testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test within 24 hours after arrival    2) People coming in from high risk countries have to get tested and also self isolate. However, those who are previously infected or fully vaccinated and have permanent residence or a residence permit in an EU-, Schengen- or OECD-country* or one of the COVID-19 risk countries/regions are exempted. Those with a valid certificate of vaccination are also exempted    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211115181454/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/categorization-of-countries

1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents coming in EU/Schengen, OECD countries or  COVID-19 risk countries, can enter Denmark without testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected must take a test before/within 24 hours after arrival.    2) People coming in from high risk countries have to get tested and also self isolate. However, those who are previously infected or fully vaccinated and have permanent residence or a residence permit in an EU-, Schengen- or OECD-country* or one of the COVID-19 risk countries/regions are exempted. Those with a valid certificate of vaccination are also exempted    3)  People coming in from areas with COVID-19 variants of concern within 10 days prior to the date of entering Denmark, must take a test within 24 hours of entry and immediately self-isolate for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least four days after arrival. Those who  have stayed in a country, region or area with COVID-19 variants of concern between 5 and 10 days before entry to Denmark, can interrupt the isolation by a negative PCR test, which is performed immediately after entry, and otherwise with a negative PCR test, which is performed at the earliest on the fourth day after entry    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127110428/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/categorization-of-countries

The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least six days after arrival. Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127105143/https://www.sst.dk/da/Covid-vaccination-5-11aar

1. Residents in nursing homes, assisted living, etc.    2. People aged = 65 who receive both personal care and practical assistance.    3. People aged = 85 years.    4. Personnel in healthcare, elderly care and selected parts of the social sector who are at particular risk of infection or who has been identified as performing a critical function in society.    5. Selected persons with conditions and diseases that result in a significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19.    6. Selected relatives of individuals at significantly increased risk of a severe illness from COVID-19 or relatives who are indispensable as caregivers.    7. People aged 80-84.    8. People aged 75-79.    9. People aged 65-74.    10 A. People aged 60-64 (born between 1957 and 1961).    10 B. People aged 55-59 (born between 1962 and 1966).    10 C. People aged 50-54 (born between 1967 and 1971).    10 D1. People aged 16-19 and 45-49 years (born 1972-1976 and 2002-2005).    10 D2. People aged 20-24 and 40-44 years (born 1977-1981 and 1997-2001).    10 D3. People aged 25-29 and 35-39 years (born 1982-1986 and 1992-1996).    10 D4. People aged 30-34 (born 1987-1991).    11. People aged 12-15 (born 2006-2009). Children, who turn 12 in 2021 will be invited by date of birth and as they turn 12.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202162815/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Vaccination%20against%20COVID-19/Who%20should%20be%20vaccinated

Everyone can get vaccinated - except children under the age of 12. Children who turn 12 during 2021 will be offered vaccination when they turn 12. However, in exceptional cases, for example in the event of severe illness, a child under the age of 12 may be offered vaccination based on an individual, medical assessment. Masks and social distancing measures are recommended only, not mandatory.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211212200427/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/education-pre-schools-hobby-education-sport-continuous-education/general-education-vocational-education-higher-education

Workplaces are open but the employers must evaluate the risks present in the working environment and enact measures to lower the risks: these measures can include requirement to wear a mask, testing, vaccination, re-organisation of work...  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212200704/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/work-economy-and-business/work-during-the-emergency-situation

At entertainment public establishments indoors it is obligatory for all persons from the age of 12 years and three months to present a valid COVID certificate   https://web.archive.org/web/20211212201305/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/public-services-and-everyday-life/culture-and-entertainment

In public spaces, gathering requires Covid certificates for all people over 12. The restriction does not apply to private events in private places.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212201305/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/public-services-and-everyday-life/culture-and-entertainment

Masks must be worn in public transports for people over 12, but Covid certificates are not required. https://web.archive.org/web/20211212201950/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/public-services-and-everyday-life/public-transport-within-estonia
There is no stay at home requirement  https://web.archive.org/web/20211019023600/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en
There is no restriction   https://web.archive.org/web/20211019023600/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en

Persons who are travelling from the list of red countries would require to quarantine for 10 days. Restrictions depend on the country of arrival. The period of self-isolation can be shortened with a COVID test.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211122111600/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/travelling-commercial-freight/travelling-to-estonia---estonian-citizens-and-residents    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120052234/https://vm.ee/sites/default/files/citizens_and_residents_of_the_european_union_19_11.pdf

Depending on the country of origins, travelers may have to fill up a questionnaire, get tested or quarantine. From December 1 to December 15, the list of risk countries is extended to include countries where Omicron is present.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211212202440/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/travelling-commercial-freight/travelling-to-estonia---foreigners
No income support provided, only sick days  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212202646/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/work-economy-and-business/incapacity-benefit-payments---sick-days-care-leave
No debt relief announced for households  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212202646/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/work-economy-and-business/incapacity-benefit-payments---sick-days-care-leave
There is an updated government website  https://web.archive.org/web/20211019023600/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en

In most cases, family physicians or the Health Board must refer their patients to testing. Specific providers can also provide tests for a fee to anyone who wants to be tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212203305/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/testing-for-the-virus
Contact tracing is done through the HOIA app   https://web.archive.org/web/20211212203516/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/hoia-mobile-app

A protective mask is obligatory in public indoor spaces (including rooms where COVID certificate is checked, e.g. cinema, theatre, events, trainings etc).   https://web.archive.org/web/20211212203725/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/personal-protection-equipment---masks-and-similar
In 2021, vaccination is free for everybody who lives in Estonia, over the age of 12 https://web.archive.org/web/20211212203903/https://vaktsineeri.ee/en/covid-19/vaccination-in-estonia/

Recommendations of sanitary measures are made for visitors of care homes. There is also a policy that the care homes have to follow in case of suspicion of infection.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211212204216/https://www.kriis.ee/en/everyday-life-and-services/medical-aid-pharmacies-and-social-care/social-care
In 2021, vaccination is free for everybody who lives in Estonia, over the age of 12 https://web.archive.org/web/20211212203903/https://vaktsineeri.ee/en/covid-19/vaccination-in-estonia/

In 2021, vaccination is free for everybody who lives in Estonia, including those who do not have health insurance.  Vaccination is voluntary.  All Estonian people (over the age of 12) can get vaccinated against COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211126184705/https://vaktsineeri.ee/en/covid-19/vaccination-in-estonia/
Everyone above 12 can get the vaccine  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212203903/https://vaktsineeri.ee/en/covid-19/vaccination-in-estonia/

The Nationwide Telework recommendation has ended, however, workplaces can continue to combine teleworking and physical/present work.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211101122717/https://www.proquest.com/docview/2576735855

The Nationwide Telework recommendation has ended, however, workplaces can continue to combine teleworking and physical/present work.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211101122717/https://www.proquest.com/docview/2576735855

The Nationwide Telework recommendation has now been reintroduced in areas currently experiencing increased levels of community transmission.   The recommendation is for all employees in the public sector to work remotely as extensively as possible if their duties so allow. The Government also recommends that private employers adopt similar extensive remote work practices, recognising, however, that workplaces will determine how to combine in-office and remote work in a way that ensures health security.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216145328/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/10623/government-recommends-remote-work-in-areas-in-the-community-transmission-phase-until-further-notice

Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory    The Finnish Institute of Health and Welfare recommends avoiding all travel to South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Lesotho, Eswatini (Swaziland), Malawi and Mozambique based on the new COVID-19 variant (B.1.1.529)    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127120233/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory    The Finnish Institute of Health and Welfare has restricted all travel to South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Lesotho, Eswatini (Swaziland), Malawi and Mozambique based on the new COVID-19 variant (B.1.1.529) from 27th November. Entry from these regions is also restricted and only allowed under certain circumstances.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212152923/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212153700/https://raja.fi/en/guidelines-for-border-traffic-during-pandemic

The amendment to the unemployment benefit legislation will be extended until 30 November 2021. Those laid off temporarily and the lay-off started on or after 16 March 2020, are eligible for an unemployment benefit even if they are studying. This is a temporary change that will be effective until 31 December 2021.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211017165013/https://www.kela.fi/web/en/unemployment-benefit-corona

Testing is recommended not only for those who are symptomatic, but also for those among these group who have been exposed to the virus:  those who are unvaccinated, those have received only one vaccine dose of a series of two doses, those are fully vaccinated but less than a week has elapsed since the second dose of the vaccine and have been exposed to coronavirus within the last two weeks, and those who belong to a group for which a third dose of vaccine is recommended, but you have not yet received a third dose.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202170009/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/symptoms-and-treatment-coronavirus/coronavirus-tests

Testing is generally available but specificall recommended not only for those who are symptomatic, but also for those among these group who have been exposed to the virus: those who are unvaccinated, those have received only one vaccine dose of a series of two doses, those are fully vaccinated but less than a week has elapsed since the second dose of the vaccine and have been exposed to coronavirus within the last two weeks, and those who belong to a group for which a third dose of vaccine is recommended, but you have not yet received a third dose.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202170009/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/symptoms-and-treatment-coronavirus/coronavirus-tests

A mobile app "Koronavilkku",  is a contact tracing app was produced by the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) to help people find out whether you may have been exposed to coronavirus. The app can also be used to send share positive tests results anonymously with those you have been in close contact with.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210820141655/https://koronavilkku.fi/en

The Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare recommends that COVID-19 vaccinations are offered to different groups in the following order:    1. Health care personnel caring for COVID-19 patients, personnel and residents in round-the-clock care units, other social welfare and health care personnel providing urgent care, and election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting  1.1. Personnel in intensive care units    1.2. Personnel in hospital wards and emergency care for diagnosed or suspected COVID-19 patients    1.3. Personnel at facilities for diagnosed or suspected COVID-19 patients, coronavirus testing personnel, and laboratory personnel involved in coronavirus diagnostics    1.4. Personnel and residents in social services for residential care and enhanced institutional, round-the-clock care units    1.5. Other social welfare and health care personnel providing urgent care    In group 1.5, a limited number of social welfare and health care personnel working in functions that are considered urgent and critical by the region can be vaccinated against COVID-19. These functions are essential for guaranteeing the patientsâ statutory right to urgent treatment.    Such groups of essential personnel include:    Acute psychiatry unit personnel  Essential staff for units providing urgent care (such as round-the-clock emergency clinics and daytime emergency clinics)  Surgical and operative unit personnel providing emergency or urgent care  Personnel providing emergency or urgent care at wards  Personnel dealing with births  Personnel at emergency social work for substance abuse   Personnel at emergency services for child welfare  1.6. Election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting    As of 19 April 2021, according to an amendment to the Government decree, the election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting in the 2021 municipal elections will be treated as section 1 of the vaccination order.    This group includes the chairpersons, vice-chairpersons, members and deputy members of the electoral committees referred to in section 15 of the Election Act (714/1998) and the electoral commissioners responsible for at-home voting referred to in section 17.    Election boards are not included in this group.    2. The elderly, and persons with underlying conditions that predispose to severe COVID-19  Elderly persons are at the greatest risk for severe COVID-19 disease. Certain underlying conditions also predispose to severe COVID-19.    2.1. = 80-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*                  2.2. 75â79-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*    2.3. 70â74-year-olds, and carers living in the same household    2.4. 12â69-year-olds with a highly predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    2.5. 12â69-year-olds with a predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    * When vaccinating persons aged 70 or over, all those aged 70 or over living in the same household can be vaccinated at the same time when the oldest member of the household is eligible for vaccination, if this is feasible with regard to practical arrangements.    THL recommends that persons in terminal care should not be vaccinated. A decision on the vaccination of persons with fragile health is always made on a case-by-case basis in cooperation with the treating physician, the person being vaccinated and their family members.    Coronavirus vaccination order for risk groups    Press release 5.2.2021: THL has detailed medical risk groups for coronavirus vaccines     3. Others  According to a Government decree that entered into force on 19 April 2021, the rest of the population will be vaccinated by age group starting from the oldest age group.    3.1. 60â69-year-olds    3.2. 50â59-year-olds    3.3. 40â49-year-olds    3.4. 30â39-year-olds    3.5. 16â29-year-olds    3.5. 12â15-year-olds    Social welfare and health care personnel not included in groups 1.1â1.5 are vaccinated based on age along with the rest of the population.     Children under the age of 12 are not yet vaccinated, as no coronavirus vaccine in use has yet been authorised for children under that age.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211118025346/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/vaccines-and-coronavirus/vaccination-order-and-at-risk-groups-for-covid-19

THL recommends third vaccine doses for the following groups:    persons 60 years of age or over   persons living in institutions and care homes   persons in medical high-risk groups  persons whose immune defence has weakened to a great degree  persons who have been vaccinated at a short vaccination interval of less than 6 weeks. The Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare recommends that COVID-19 vaccinations are offered to different groups in the following order:    1. Health care personnel caring for COVID-19 patients, personnel and residents in round-the-clock care units, other social welfare and health care personnel providing urgent care, and election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting  1.1. Personnel in intensive care units    1.2. Personnel in hospital wards and emergency care for diagnosed or suspected COVID-19 patients    1.3. Personnel at facilities for diagnosed or suspected COVID-19 patients, coronavirus testing personnel, and laboratory personnel involved in coronavirus diagnostics    1.4. Personnel and residents in social services for residential care and enhanced institutional, round-the-clock care units    1.5. Other social welfare and health care personnel providing urgent care    In group 1.5, a limited number of social welfare and health care personnel working in functions that are considered urgent and critical by the region can be vaccinated against COVID-19. These functions are essential for guaranteeing the patientsâ statutory right to urgent treatment.    Such groups of essential personnel include:    Acute psychiatry unit personnel  Essential staff for units providing urgent care (such as round-the-clock emergency clinics and daytime emergency clinics)  Surgical and operative unit personnel providing emergency or urgent care  Personnel providing emergency or urgent care at wards  Personnel dealing with births  Personnel at emergency social work for substance abuse   Personnel at emergency services for child welfare  1.6. Election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting    As of 19 April 2021, according to an amendment to the Government decree, the election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting in the 2021 municipal elections will be treated as section 1 of the vaccination order.    This group includes the chairpersons, vice-chairpersons, members and deputy members of the electoral committees referred to in section 15 of the Election Act (714/1998) and the electoral commissioners responsible for at-home voting referred to in section 17.    Election boards are not included in this group.    2. The elderly, and persons with underlying conditions that predispose to severe COVID-19  Elderly persons are at the greatest risk for severe COVID-19 disease. Certain underlying conditions also predispose to severe COVID-19.    2.1. = 80-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*                  2.2. 75â79-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*    2.3. 70â74-year-olds, and carers living in the same household    2.4. 12â69-year-olds with a highly predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    2.5. 12â69-year-olds with a predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    * When vaccinating persons aged 70 or over, all those aged 70 or over living in the same household can be vaccinated at the same time when the oldest member of the household is eligible for vaccination, if this is feasible with regard to practical arrangements.    THL recommends that persons in terminal care should not be vaccinated. A decision on the vaccination of persons with fragile health is always made on a case-by-case basis in cooperation with the treating physician, the person being vaccinated and their family members.    Coronavirus vaccination order for risk groups    Press release 5.2.2021: THL has detailed medical risk groups for coronavirus vaccines     3. Others  According to a Government decree that entered into force on 19 April 2021, the rest of the population will be vaccinated by age group starting from the oldest age group.    3.1. 60â69-year-olds    3.2. 50â59-year-olds    3.3. 40â49-year-olds    3.4. 30â39-year-olds    3.5. 16â29-year-olds    3.5. 12â15-year-olds    Social welfare and health care personnel not included in groups 1.1â1.5 are vaccinated based on age along with the rest of the population.     Children under the age of 12 are not yet vaccinated, as no coronavirus vaccine in use has yet been authorised for children under that age.
