No change in policy    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212154240/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/vaccines-and-coronavirus/vaccination-order-and-at-risk-groups-for-covid-19

No change in policy    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212154240/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/vaccines-and-coronavirus/vaccination-order-and-at-risk-groups-for-covid-19

No change in policy, all schools remain at the Level 2/Yellow level introduced on 15 November, irrespective of the incidence rate of Covid-19 in the local population. https://web.archive.org/web/20211205060819/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

From 9 December, all primary schools are moved to Level 3/Orage level restrictions; facial coverings are required in playgrounds and contact sports are restricted. Masks continue to be required when inside for all staff and students aged 6 and over. https://web.archive.org/web/20211215185154/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

No change to the policy implemented on 9 December: all primary schools are moved to Level 3/Orage level restrictions; facial coverings are required in playgrounds and contact sports are restricted. Masks continue to be required when inside for all staff and students aged 6 and over. Classes will be closed and learning moved online if there are more than 3 cases of COVID-19 in a particular class. In universities, barrier protection is required, masks are mandatory, and student who test positive and their contacts must self-isolate for 7 days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211226182600/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20211128075403/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus and  https://web.archive.org/web/20211126150822/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Use of the Health Pass is required for access to many workplaces by both employees and customers. From 9 December, discotheques are to be closed for a period of at least 4 weeks. The government recommends that 2 or 3 days per week of remote working are implemented in work environments where teleworking is possible, face-to-face meetings should be limited, and welcome and leaving ceremonies should be postponed.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20211207210635/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus  - https://web.archive.org/web/20211209195104/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Use of the Health Pass is required for access to many workplaces by both employees and customers. From 9 December, discotheques are to be closed until 6 January 2022, mand dancing in restaurants and bars is prohibited until the same date. The government recommends that 2 or 3 days per week of remote working are implemented in work environments where teleworking is possible, face-to-face meetings should be limited, and welcome and leaving ceremonies should be postponed.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211224033327/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20211222062141/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire
Use of the Health Pass continues to be required for access to public events. https://web.archive.org/web/20211215185255/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Use of the Health Pass is required to access almost all public events. Prefects in all Departments are authorized to prohibit public events and gatherings, consumption of alcohol in public places, and are recommended to prohibit public events including fireworks and concerts where barrier methods cannot be implemented. https://web.archive.org/web/20211224033327/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Use of the Health Pass is required for access to access many places or events where people gather, and these rules have applied since 21 July to access places of leisure and culture (including concert halls, amusement parks, concert halls, festivals, sports halls, games rooms, libraries and documentation centres, or cinemas), and have been extended since 9 August to cover:    - commercial catering activities (bars and restaurants, including on terraces), with the exception of collective catering or take-away of prepared meals, professional road and rail catering, room service in hotel restaurants and bars and non-commercial catering, including the free distribution of meals;  - trade fairs and exhibitions, and professional seminars;  - health, social and medico-social services and institutions, for persons accompanying or visiting persons accommodated in such services and establishments as well as for those who are accommodated there for scheduled care. This measure, which applies subject to emergency cases, does not have the effect of limiting access to care;  - long-distance travel by interregional public transport (domestic flights, TGV journeys, IntercitÃ©s and night trains, interregional coaches);  - department stores and shopping centers of more than 20,000mÂ²,by decision of the prefect of the department, when their characteristics and the seriousness of the risks of contamination justify it, under conditions guaranteeing access to people to essential goods and services as well as to the means of transport accessible within the walls of these stores and centers. Currently, shopping centers of more than 20,000 mÂ² located in departments under strong epidemic pressure are subject to the "health pass" after decision of the prefects concerned;  - ski lifts and Christmas markets (unless the prefect decides otherwise);  - access to tourist accommodation such as campsites or holiday clubs is subject to the "health pass", with a single control at the beginning of the stay;  - prefects have the possibility of making the "health pass" mandatory in places of gathering or on the occasion of events,such as markets for example.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211226182727/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire    The government discourages private holiday gatherings, recommends avoiding kissing, and avoiding large gatherings of people (although there is no evidence of rules enfocing such behaviour) - https://web.archive.org/web/20211224033327/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Public transport is available throughout France, but access to long-distance travel on public transport requires use of the Health Pass. https://web.archive.org/web/20211215185255/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Local transport remains open without restriction, use of the Health Pass is required for long-distance and inter-regional travel on buses, trains and airplanes - https://web.archive.org/web/20211226182727/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire
There are no stay-at-home requirements in metropolitan France - https://web.archive.org/web/20211215193401/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
No requirements to stay at home are in place - https://web.archive.org/web/20211224033327/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
Use of the Health Pass is required for long-distance journeys on any form of public transport - https://web.archive.org/web/20211217001806/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire
Use of the Health Pass is required for long-distance journeys on any form of public transport - https://web.archive.org/web/20211226182727/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

No change in policy, entry to France remains controlled depending on the vaccination status, reason for traveling, and country of traveler origin. Origin countries are categorised as Green/Orange/Red depending on Covid-19 prevalence.     Belarus was added to the list of Red category countries on 23 November. The list is now as follows:     - "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, Chile, comoros, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, the United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu.    - "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which there is active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.    - "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Georgia, Moldova, Montenegro, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, Suriname, Turkey and Ukraine.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211123221056/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19#nav-main-menu

No change in policy, entry to France remains controlled depending on the vaccination status, reason for traveling, and country of traveler origin. Origin countries are categorised as Green/Orange/Red depending on Covid-19 prevalence.     Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, and Zimbabwe were added to the list of Red category countries on 27 November, and flights between France and those countries were suspecnded between 27 November and 3 December (https://web.archive.org/web/20211202211842/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/deplacements)     The list is now as follows:     - "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, Chile, comoros, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, the United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu.    - "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which there is active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.    - "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, Botswana, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Eswatini, Georgia, Lesotho, Moldova, Montenegro, Mozambique, Namibia, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, South Africa, Suriname, Turkey, Ukraine and Zimbabwe.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211128075535/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19#main

From 4 December at midnight, any person entering French territory from a country outside the European area must present a negative PCR or antigen test of less than 48 hours. The time for antigen tests for travel from scarlet red countries is 24 hours (see below).    "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, the Comoros, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay and Vanuatu.    "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.    "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Georgia, Moldova, Montenegro, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, Suriname, Turkey and Ukraine.    As a precautionary measure, and pending additional data on the Omicron variant, a category of "scarlet red" countries is created: particularly active circulation of the virus and/or discovery of a variant likely to present a risk of increased transmissibility or immune escape. These are: Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe.    The ability to travel from or to French territory depends on this classification and the vaccination status of travelers, for complete details see https://web.archive.org/web/20211204173746/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

From 12 December, the classification of countries is as follows:     Green: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, the Comoros, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay and Vanuatu.  Orange: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.  Red: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus with the presence of variants of concern is observed. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Georgia, Mauritius, Moldova, Montenegro, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, Suriname, Turkey and Ukraine.  Scarlet Red:  countries/territories in which a particularly active circulation of the virus is observed and/or the discovery of a variant likely to present a risk of increased transmissibility or immune escape. These are: Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe.    Details of the travel controls imposed per category are contained at https://web.archive.org/web/20211217002052/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

From 00:00 on 18 December, new rules impact travel between the United Kingdom and France due to prevalence of the Omicron variant in the UK. All travellers twelve years of age or older, regardless of vaccination status, from the United Kingdom:    - are subject to the regime of compelling reasons,the list of which is specified in the certificate of travel and travel drawn up by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France and return to their residence in the United Kingdom: french people and their spouses and children;  - must present a negative PCR or antigen (TAG) test taken less than 24 hours before flight boarding;  - must register before departure on the eOS-COVID digital platform  (https://web.archive.org/web/20211202154207/https://passager.serveureos.org/);  - may be subject to an antigen test on arrival;  - will be subject to mandatory isolation for 10 days, supervised and controlled by the security forces. This isolation obligation may be lifted from 48 hours, subject to a negative PCR or antigen test.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20211218000501/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays-destination/royaume-uni/    Restrictions for travelers from other countries remain as per the update of 12 December - https://web.archive.org/web/20211217002052/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

From 00:00 on 18 December, new rules impact travel between the United Kingdom and France due to prevalence of the Omicron variant in the UK. All travellers twelve years of age or older, regardless of vaccination status, from the United Kingdom:    - are subject to the regime of compelling reasons,the list of which is specified in the certificate of travel and travel drawn up by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France and return to their residence in the United Kingdom: french people and their spouses and children;  - must present a negative PCR or antigen (TAG) test taken less than 24 hours before flight boarding;  - must register before departure on the eOS-COVID digital platform  (https://web.archive.org/web/20211202154207/https://passager.serveureos.org/);  - may be subject to an antigen test on arrival;  - will be subject to mandatory isolation for 10 days, supervised and controlled by the security forces. This isolation obligation may be lifted from 48 hours, subject to a negative PCR or antigen test.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20211218000501/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays-destination/royaume-uni/    Restrictions for travelers from other countries remain as per the update of 12 December - https://web.archive.org/web/20211217002052/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

Vaccination is universally available to people aged over 12 years and 2 months. The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     From November 27, vaccination boosters are avaialble to all people 18 years of age and older from five months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19. From     From December 15, rules for the Health Pass are changing for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have received a booster vaccine, from the moment they are eligible (i.e. 6 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 4 additional weeks maximum. Beyond this time, their QR code will be deactivated automatically.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211128075648/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Vaccination is universally available to people aged over 12 years and 2 months. vaccination booster is open to all people aged 18 and over from five months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211207123504/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Vaccination is universally available to people aged over 12 years and two months. From 15 December, vaccination is available to children aged between 5 and 11 who are overweight or who have an underlying medical condition.     Vaccination booster is open to all people aged 18 and over from five months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    As of December 15, 2021, the rules relating to the "health pass" are changing for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have made their recall, from the moment they are eligible (5 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 8 additional weeks maximum.    People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211207123504/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

From 22 December, vaccination is universally available to people aged over 5 years and older.    Vaccination booster is available to all people aged 18 and over from five months after the last injection and one month after the second injection, or five months after recovery from infection with Covid-19.    As of December 15, 2021, the rules relating to the "health pass" are changing for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have received their booster vaccination, from the moment they are eligible (5 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 8 additional weeks maximum.    People aged 80 and over with mobility issues are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211224120928/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

In addition to the protections afforded to the general population, vaccination is mandatory for all people in contact with frail and elderly people, including caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers.     From December 15, rules for the Health Pass are changing for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have received a booster vaccine, from the moment they are eligible (i.e. 6 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 4 additional weeks maximum. Beyond this time, their QR code will be deactivated automatically.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211128075648/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

In addition to the protections afforded to the general population, vaccination is mandatory for all people in contact with frail and elderly people, including caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers.     From December 15, rules for the Health Pass have changed for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have received a booster vaccine, from the moment they are eligible (i.e. 6 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 4 additional weeks maximum. Beyond this time, their QR code will be deactivated automatically.     For people aged over 80 years of age who have mobility issues and wish to benefit from a vaccination at home can access a special toll-free number to put them in touch with services likely to offer them a vaccination at home.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211215185817/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

If you have been in direct contact with a person who has tested positive for COVID-19, you should quarantine for seven days, counting from the date of the exposure. You will be contacted by the Chief Medical Officer.  To reduce the risk of the new Omicron variant spreading in the Faroe Islands, quarantine measures are being extended. This means that everyone who has been in contact with an infected person â i.e. secondary contacts â will be quarantined, regardless of vaccine received or previous infection status.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211210234418/https://korona.fo/270?_l=en

The UK is removing all countries from its red travel list, just weeks after reactivating the list in response to the new Omicron variant.    As of tomorrow, 15 December, people arriving from 11 African countries will no longer need to stay in one of the government-run quarantine hotels.    People currently in a UK quarantine hotel will also be allowed to leave early, as long as they do not test positive for COVID-19.    However all current testing requirements will remain in place, Transport Secretary Grant Shapps confirmed on Twitter this afternoon.    he UK recently updated its travel rules, stipulating that all arrivals must now show a negative pre-departure PCR or lateral flow test that was taken within 48 hours of arriving.    This is in addition to a day 2 PCR test, which both UK citizens and visitors must await the results of in isolation. The rules vary for unvaccinated travellers.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211215095343/https://www.euronews.com/travel/2021/12/14/uk-travel-all-countries-removed-from-the-uk-s-red-quarantine-list

Cancel Public Events C3 - 2G  As of December 1, Restriction remains valid on holding the wide-scale entertainment and such social events, as wedding parties, banquets, jubilees of various types, and similar. Night clubs remain banned. entertainment activities, arts and culture events (except for stage performances and cinema), festivals are going to be fully banned.  Sports tournaments of various types may be held without spectators.   https://archive.vn/6iW0Bhttps://archive.vn/6iW0B

On December 1, cinema and theater attendances will grow from 30% to 50%. On December 1, restrictions on restaurant opening hours will be lifted. The ban on concerts and festivals is removed so long as applicable regulations are observed. Restriction remains valid on holding the wide-scale entertainment and such social events, as wedding parties, banquets, jubilees of various types and similar. Eateries and ritual venues of miscellaneous types will be sanctioned with 10 000 GEL for hosting such events but will be sealed if found in breach of the regulation for the second time.   Also, camping of any type is banned, regardless of the organizational form or venue.   Any type of entertainment activities, arts and culture events (except for stage performances and cinema), festivals are going to be fully banned. The referred restriction does not apply to concerts to be held at the premises of hotels. As for sports tournaments of various types, they may be held without spectators. Nevertheless, every participant should be vaccinated (14 days should be lapsed from the second dose) or have a PCR test result obtained in the past 72 hours or a negative result of an antigen test obtained in the past 24 hours.  Amendments have been made to Government Resolution N322 dated May 23, 2020 on the Adoption of the Rules of Isolation and Quarantine, according to which delegates will be allowed to attend conferences, trainings and seminars from July 19, 2021 only with a negative PCR test taken 72 hours prior or express antigen test taken 24 hours prior to the event and/or without the latter on the 14th day from full vaccination.   Source: https://archive.vn/qcOkW

no policy change     At level 4 (red) of the Epidemiology Charter country incorporated the Regional Units Kavala, Imathia, Pieria and Pella , while extending a special, local, measures in Regional Units Haryana and Argolis , after re-evaluation of epidemiological data the Committee of Infectious Diseases and the National Committee for the Protection of Public Health against the Covid-19 coronavirus in the context of the epidemiological surveillance of the country by Regional Unit and Municipality on a weekly basis.    At the same time, level 3 (orange) includes the Regional Units of Achaia, Ilia, Messinia, Heraklion , as well as the Municipality of Ikaria .    It is reminded that the measures in force are the following:    Traffic ban from 01:00 in the evening until 06:00 in the morning, with the exception of work and serious health reasons.  Prohibition of music around the clock in stores of health interest and entertainment.  The measures are valid from tomorrow, Friday 17 September at 06.00 until Friday 24 September at 6:00 .    It is also reminded that in these areas, as well as in the whole territory, it is forbidden to hold any form of events in exchange for any form of exchange, with the physical presence of a crowd of more than twenty (20) people in a private, non-professional space . The administrative fine in case of violation amounts from 50,000 to 200,000 euros for the lessee or concessionaire of the private, non-professional space, in which the said event took place or takes place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210919221253/https://www.civilprotection.gr/el/simantika-themata/sto-epipedo-4-toy-epidimiologikoy-harti-tis-horas-kavala-imathia-pieria-kai-pella

The gov.gr covid19 information website states that for these red areas,    "4. Prohibition of any kind of gathering of citizens for over 9 people for any reason, both in public and in private."    https://web.archive.org/https://covid19.gov.gr/covid-map-en/

no policy change     Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  a self-test declaration signed less than 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  Travel in Greece  Travel within Greece between Regional Units is permitted subject to adherence to public health measures as outlined above. You must wear a mask at all times on all public transport.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding.    If you are travelling by internal (domestic) flights, specific measures relating to check-in, baggage allowances and other details are in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. You should check with your operator directly for further detail.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210802101710/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

Guidelines for when a child is suspected of being infected at a primary school, recreational activities, day care institution, etc.:  1. Persons with COVID-19 symptoms should isolate and get tested as quickly as possible.  2. Anyone with symptoms should be kept separate from the other children, pupils, students and employees until they can be collected or sent home, and all of the probable contact points must be cleaned (e.g. the seating in the classroom, doorknobs, handles, handrails etc., that the person or child with symptoms may have touched).  A negative PCR test will mean the tested person or child is no longer suspected of having COVID-19.  If it is ascertained there is infection among the pupils or teachers, the next steps will be clarified in collaboration with the municipality and the National Board of Health in Greenland (âLandslÃ¦geembedetâ) in accordance with the applicable rules for the area.    Basic principles for handling cases in relation to primary schools and day care institutions:  1.The day care institution or primary school should not allow any child or pupil who is infected or who is a close contact of an infected child or pupil from attending the institution or primary school.  2. The pupils can be tested, if required several times, rather than sending them home. The times for testing will depend on the specific case.  3. Children who do not have COVID-19 symptoms and whose parents do not want them to be tested, are recommended to remain at home for 14 days after their last near contact with the infected person.  4. Parents or other family members or people who live with the children who are near contacts, only need to pay extra attention to the infection prevention advice, including in relation to hygiene and airing out.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206122147/https://corona.nun.gl/en/at-the-workplace/guidelines-for-primary-schools-day-care-and-after-school-activities/

Rules relating to the workplace:  Naalakkersuisut might introduce restrictions that affect the workplace and businesses in general. Youâll find the latest official announcement here.  Certain rules may apply only to specific cities or areas. E.g. local restrictions regarding face masks or access to public localities.  (*NO CURRENT LOCAL RESTRICTIONS)  - Workplaces, educational institutions, etc. should clearly mark entrances with signs stating that access is prohibited for persons with COVID-19 symptoms and should have clear procedures in place for the handling of personnel, students, visitors etc. with COVID-19 symptoms, including how working at home/studying at home can be organised.  - Face masks must be worn by cabin crew when flying to and from Greenland, and for domestic flights in Greenland. If your duties include passenger contact in the airport terminal areas or similar, you must wear a face mask or a face shield visor if you cannot set up a plastic screen between yourself and travellers.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211202091659/https://corona.nun.gl/en/at-the-workplace/suliffeqarfimmi-malittarisassat-2-3/

Important information for businesses:  -Naalakkersuisut might introduce restrictions that affect the workplace and businesses in general. Youâll find the latest official announcement *here.  -Certain rules may apply only to specific cities or areas. E.g. local restrictions regarding face masks or access to public localities. Please find information about any current local restrictions *here. Please note that the page might be in Danish.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212154457/https://corona.nun.gl/en/at-the-workplace/suliffeqarfimmi-malittarisassat-2-3/    *Area restrictions  These dwellings are currently contagious from unknown sources of infection and therefore subject to special restrictions: Nuuk, Qasigiannguit, Upernavik, Tasiusaq, Upernavik Kujalleq, Nutaarmiut, Nuussuaq, Innaarsuit, Naajaat, Aappilattoq, Kangersuatsiaq, Kullorsuaq.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212154716/https://corona.nun.gl/da/omraderestriktioner/    They also had to update their website tab from 'At the workplace' to becoming 'Business'.

In Nuuk, Upernavik and Qasigiannguit , there is a requirement for vaccination against COVID-19 for people who are present in locations and associated areas that have public access. The requirements apply to all citizens over the age of 2. This means that children at the age of 2-12 do not have access unless they have previously been infected and have a positive PCR-test that is between 14 days and 12 weeks old. Shown below is information relating to the access requirement in Nuuk, Upernavik and Qasigiannguit. You must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 You are only allowed access to the following places if you are fully vaccinated against COVID-19: 1) Restaurants, cafes, pubs, discos and similar establishments and their adjoining outdoor areas. 2) Cultural institutions, including culture centres, cinemas, museums, exhibition halls, etc. 3) Community centres and similar establishments. 4) Libraries. 5) Indoor and outdoor sports facilities, including sports colleges and sports halls, swimming pools, gyms, football pitches, etc. 6) Hairdressers, massage parlours, beauty clinics and similar establishments. 7) Retail stores/shops that are not grocery stores.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206124730/https://corona.nun.gl/en/corona-passport-digital-eu-covid-certificate/vaccination-as-a-requirement-for-access/

In Greenland, there is a requirement for vaccination against COVID-19 or a negative PCR test, which is a maximum of 48 hours old, for people who want to stay in premises and associated areas with public access.  -You are only allowed access to the following places if you are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or have a negative PCR test that is a maximum of 48 hours old:  1) Restaurants, cafes, pubs, discos and similar establishments and their adjoining outdoor areas.  2) Cultural institutions, including culture centres, cinemas, museums, exhibition halls, etc.  3) Community centres and similar establishments.  4) Libraries.  5) Indoor and outdoor sports facilities, including sports colleges and sports halls, swimming pools, gyms, football pitches, etc.  6) Hairdressers, massage parlours, beauty clinics and similar establishments.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212155747/https://corona.nun.gl/en/corona-passport-digital-eu-covid-certificate/vaccination-as-a-requirement-for-access/

In public transport passengers can be helped to keep their distance and reduce the number of contacts by e.g. limiting mobility, limiting standing passengers by using booked seating, reducing the possibility of passengers moving around and between each other, etc.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206130814/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/infection-prevention-advice/

Public transportation is open but depending on the vaccination status in relation to domestic travel in Greenland.    -If you travel from a city or settlement to another place within the countryâs borders, you must be fully vaccinated or have a negative test that is no more than 48 hours old at the time of departure.  -The owner of the means of transportation is responsible for ensuring that all travellers obey the rules.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212160622/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/domestic-travel-in-greenland/

Stay at home and isolate if you have COVID-19 symptoms, have tested positive or is not vaccinated and is a close contact to someone who is infected with the coronavirus.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206130814/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/infection-prevention-advice/

Local restrictions:  Requirements when travelling out of Nuuk, Upernavik and Qasigiannguit   People aged 12+ travelling from Nuuk, Upernavik or Qasigiannguit to another place in Greenland must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19. You are considered fully vaccinated against COVID-19 when you have completed a vaccination process and can document this.  If you are fully vaccinated, you donât need to show a negative PCR-test result when travelling out of Nuuk, Upernavik or Qasigiannguit.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211120233821/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/domestic-travel-in-greenland/

Domestic travel in Greenland:  -If you travel from a city or settlement to another place within the countryâs borders, you must be fully vaccinated or have a negative test that is no more than 48 hours old at the time of departure.  -The owner of the means of transportation is responsible for ensuring that all travellers obey the rules.  -Unvaccinated people over the age of 2 years old traveling out of a city or settlement where it is not possible to be tested must quarantine at their destination for 14 days, or until they get a negative PCR test. If it is not possible to get a PCR test at the destination, they must quarantine for 14 days.  -If you are in quarantine, you are not allowed to attend events or gatherings. You may go and get tested and go to grocery stores to make necessary purchases if you wear face masks or visors.  -Children under the age of 2 are exempt from the requirement of showing documentation of a test.  -If you have previously been infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 weeks, and you are able to document this, the same rules apply to you as to fully vaccinated people.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212160622/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/domestic-travel-in-greenland/

Updated policy for 'Travel from a place where you canât get tested â no spread of infection' for 'Unvaccinated 12 yrs old or older' from 'Test Requirement (<48 hours)' to 'Quarantine upon Arrival'.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211220212138/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/domestic-travel-in-greenland/

To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated or a resident of Greenland or you are relocating to Greenland. In regard to entering Greenland, you are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after your last dose.  When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -You must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test from a Nordic country (Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland, Iceland, Faroe Islands), UK, Liechtenstein, Switzerland, or a country in EU that is maximum 72 hours old from the time of departure and have valid documentation showing this.  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport.  Special rules apply if you have previously been infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 weeks.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206132419/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

*Changed PCR swab tests validity from maximum 72 hrs to maximum 48 hrs old    Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated or a resident of Greenland or you are relocating to Greenland. In regard to entering Greenland, you are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after your last dose.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -You must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test from a Nordic country (Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland, Iceland, Faroe Islands), UK, Liechtenstein, Switzerland, or a country in EU that is maximum 48 hours old from the time of departure and have valid documentation showing this.  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport, and also during transport to your place of residence. This rule applies to everyone at 12 years old or older.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206211801/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated or a resident of Greenland or you are relocating to Greenland.    -In regard to entering Greenland, you are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -You must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test from a Nordic country (Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland, Iceland, Faroe Islands), UK, Liechtenstein, Switzerland, or a country in EU that is maximum 48 hours old from the time of departure and have valid documentation showing this.  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport, and also during transport to your place of residence. This rule applies to everyone at 12 years old or older.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211220215011/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

In addition, the Corona Secretariat acting for the National Board of Health in Greenland will contact you within 24 hours in order to trace your close contacts, i.e. the people who have been in close physical contact and as a result may have been infected.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206141614/https://corona.nun.gl/en/infection-and-symptoms/if-you-test-positive/

Face masks can be used as a supplement for preventing the spread of infection in situations where it is difficult to keep to distance. It is important that you continue to follow the advice relating to keeping a distance and good hygiene even when you wear a face mask.  In Greenland, you must wear a face mask in the following situations:  All individuals aged 12 years or older on domestic or international flights (face masks must be worn to the quarantine location/end destination).  If you have been infected or risk of being infected with COVID-19 and in exceptional circumstances must move outside, e.g. because you need to get tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211126065122/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/use-of-face-masks-and-visors/

All people registered as residing in Greenland and who are aged 12 years or older, including pregnant women and women who are breast feeding, are eligible for vaccination against COVID-19. The vaccine is free and voluntary.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206143701/https://corona.nun.gl/en/vaccination-against-covid-19/covid-19-vaccination-programme/

In general, elderly people who also have several and serious chronic conditions are at a higher risk than people who only have a single mild chronic condition. There may also be social circumstances, for example, your abode situation, which overall can mean you are in a higher risk group.    Good advice for people at a higher risk:  In general, if you are someone who is at a higher risk, you can continue to do the things you did before the COVID-19 pandemic, e.g. go to work, participate in leisure activities and take care of your grandchildren.  If before the COVID-19 pandemic, you had to follow special precautions in your daily life to avoid being infected with an infectious disease, e.g. you have a special condition and are immunocompromised, you should continue to follow those precautions.    The National Board of Health in Greenland (âLandslÃ¦geembedetâ) recommends the following for persons who are at a higher risk:  -Get re-vaccinated  -Follow the recommendations from the Office of the Medical Director of Health and ask others to be mindful  -Avoid large events and gatherings of people where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider using a face mask in public spaces where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider talking with your workplace about how to ensure that you can go to work safely    *Risk groups and highly vulnerable people  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112153916/https://corona.nun.gl/en/information-about-covid-19/

Fines for Non-Compliance:  Health Inspectors of the Croatian State Inspectorate are monitoring and enforcing individual orders to self-isolate. They are authorized to fine any individual violating this order with fines ranging from 8000 HRK for the first violation to 30,000 HRK, 60,000 HRK and 120,000 HRK for repeat offenders. Persons violating health inspector orders may also be subject to criminal charges.  People caught not wearing a mask (or improperly wearing a mask) in mask-designated areas will be fined 500 HRK, but they will be eligible to pay half that amount (250 HRK) if they agree to put on a mask immediately.  Legal entities will be fined 10,000-40,000 HRK if they do not respect the epidemiological measures related to public gatherings.  Businesses will be fined 5,000-10,000 HRK for not implementing epidemiological measures.  Passengers in transit (individuals in transit have 12 hours to exit the country, and they must show that they can enter or transit through the neighboring country). Fines in violation of this provision range from 5,000 to 10,000 HRK.    Restrictions for Individuals and Businesses  Businesses and individuals may be restricted due to the epidemiological measures based on your location in Croatia. Most notable epidemiological restrictions may include a requirement to wear a mask indoors unless seated in a restaurant or coffee shop. Venues hosting larger audiences may require visitors to present a negative COVID-19 test or record of vaccination. Some venues like night clubs or concert halls offer onsite rapid testing services for a fee. Wedding parties of up to 120 guests are permitted with a mandate that all guests, staff, and entertainers must have been vaccinated or recovered from COVID-19 or have a negative viral test.    Individual counties and cities may have additional measures. Please visit?the?Croatian Governmentâs COVID-19 website?for additional information.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211206183854/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Decision on the security measure of a temporary ban on entry into the Republic of Croatia for persons coming from the Republic of South Africa, Botswana, the Kingdom of Eswatini, Lesotho, Namibia, Zimbabwe and Hong Kong (26 November 2021)    https://web.archive.org/web/20211129195804/https://www.koronavirus.hr/odluke-stozera-civilne-zastite-za-sprjecavanje-%C5%A1irenja-zaraze-novim-koronavirusom/323

https://web.archive.org/web/20211206181205/https://www.koronavirus.hr/uploads/Upute_za_putnike_koji_dolaze_iz_drzava_za_koje_se_pri_dolasku_u_Republiku_Hrvatsku_primjenjuju_posebne_epidemioloske_mjere_prilikom_prelaska_granice_2_fc073c3315.pdf    * Translation*     Instructions for travelers coming from countries for which special epidemiological measures are applied when crossing the border upon arrival in the Republic of Croatia  version 2.12.2012  â¢ When arriving from the following countries / regions, special epidemiological measures are applied (Decision on security measure of temporary ban on entry into the Republic of Croatia for persons coming from South Africa, Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Hong Kong and Mozambique). crossing the border of the Republic of Croatia:  Travelers coming from South Africa, Botswana, the Kingdom of Eswatini, Lesotho, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Hong Kong and the Republic of Mozambique are required to undergo a 14-day quarantine / self-isolation measure and mandatory SARS-CoV-2 virus testing on the last day of quarantine. It is recommended to test passengers from these countries immediately upon arrival in Croatia, ie. at the beginning of quarantine. Evidence of illness and vaccination does not release you from the obligation to obtain a negative PCR test and quarantine travelers coming from these countries.  â¢ The following measures are applied to arrivals from the following countries on the basis of the Decision on temporary prohibition and restriction of crossings at the border crossings of the Republic of Croatia:  Passengers coming from Zanzibar (Tanzania) are required to present a negative PCR finding not older than 72 hours and are assigned the necessary quarantine / self-isolation measure for 14 days. Persons may shorten quarantine / self-isolation if, at the earliest on the seventh day of self-isolation, they perform a PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 at their own expense at an institution authorized to perform PCR testing and the test is negative. Evidence of illness and vaccination does not release you from the obligation to obtain a negative PCR test and quarantine travelers coming from these countries.  Upon arrival from Brazil, it is mandatory to present a negative nasopharyngeal swab (nasal part of the pharynx). A negative smear test should not be older than 48 hours if a rapid antigen test was performed or 72 hours if a NAAT / PCR test was performed from the time the swab was taken until entry into Croatia.
No change in prior policy

The strict recorded rules (in place as of 1st December) state: From December 1, travelers arriving from South Africa, Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Zimbabwe, Namibia and Hong Kong, or those who have visited any of these destinations in the past 14 days, are not permitted to enter Croatia due to the discovery of the Omicron variant.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211220233356/https://edition.cnn.com/travel/article/croatia-travel-covid-19/index.html

Under the same timeframe as previously  Aid to preserve jobs - short-time work scheme for 2021  The aid is granted for temporary introduction of the short-time work scheme for employees in a manner that employees work full time, but shorter than the usual monthly fund of working hours, up to a maximum of 90% of working hours. At the annual level there the short-time work scheme cannot cover more than 70% of the annual fund of working hours.    The aid is calculated based on the formula whereas HRK 4,000 (approx. EUR 525) is divided by the monthly fund of hours for the month the aid is being requested for,and multiplied by the number of hours covered by the aid. The amount of aid is calculated in accordance with HZZâs Table of the financing amount based on the number and percentage of working hours available on this link. The aid can amount to up to HRK 3,600 (approx. EUR 475) per employee.    The employers have to apply for the aid each month for the following month.     The employer must pay the full monthly salary and calculate and pay the social security contributions for the whole salary (including the part covered by the aid). If the aid is granted, it will be paid for the previous month and the State will refund the contributions to the employer.    The aid may be granted only for employees that have been employed on the last day of the month preceding the month for which the aid is requested, excluding workers on notice period, teleworkers, outsourced workers, workers on annual or another leave. Also, workers covered by the aid may not work overtime nor be replaced by other workers.    The aid will be available for months from 1 January to 31 December 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211109113252/https://cms.law/en/int/expert-guides/cms-expert-guide-to-state-aid-in-the-eu-during-coronavirus-crisis/croatia
Current policy applies until the end of 2021
No change in prior policy, as measures last till end of 2021
No change in prior policy

3. CAN I GET VACCINATED AGAINST SARS-COV-2 OUTSIDE MY RESIDENCE?  If you are not able to be vaccinated in your place of residence, or with the chosen family doctor, you can apply for vaccination via the portal cijepise.zdravlje.hr or the competent county public health institute in the place of your current residence.     4. CAN PERSONS WITH EUROPEAN HEALTH INSURANCE BE VACCINATED?  According to the instructions of the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Croatia, vaccination of persons who are insured by the Croatian Health Insurance Institute is currently underway, and therefore it is currently not possible to vaccinate persons who are not in this category.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211114221151/https://koronavirus.hr/o-covidu/892    COVID-19 Vaccine Information:  Has the government of Croatia approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Yes  Are vaccines available in Croatia for U.S. citizens to receive? Yes  Which vaccines are available in Croatia? PfizerâBioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson.  According to the Croatian Institute for Public Health, foreigners with temporary or permanent residency in Croatia can register for the COVID-19 vaccine through their local healthcare provider.  If you have an OIB (Croatian Personal Identification Number) and a local health insurance plan, you may visit https://cijepise.zdravlje.hr/ to register to get vaccinated.  If you do not have a local health insurance plan, you may visit the following Croatian Institute of Public Health website for the contact details of the county public health institutes to register by phone.  Visit the FDAâs website to?learn more about FDA-approved vaccines?in the United States.  The United States Government does not plan to provide COVID-19 vaccinations to private U.S. citizens overseas. Please follow host country developments and guidelines for COVID-19 vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211122084519/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

(translated)     (translated)    Vaccination organization . Vaccination is planned according to the Vaccination Plan.  First it  is planned to vaccinate employees and users of homes for the elderly (and other institutions for the provision of accommodation in the social welfare system) and health professionals, then (conditionally speaking, the  second phase of vaccination ) all persons over 65 and all persons with chronic diseases, and finally (conditionally speaking, the third phase ) the entire population.    The public health institutes will organize the distribution / collection of vaccines in their field, if necessary with the help of the Civil Protection Headquarters (CZ).    Vaccines differ in the method of storage, the method of storage in refrigerators at the place of vaccination and the method of use of the vaccine itself.    The first vaccine to be registered and immediately distributed in the EU Member States is the Pfizer / BioNTech vaccine (trademark Comirnaty), for which the European Medicines Agency on 21.12.2020. gave a positive opinion on the release.    https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-prevenciji/uputa-priprema-za-cijepljenje-protiv-covid-19-884/884

According to the Croatian Institute for Public Health, foreigners with temporary or permanent residency in Croatia can register for the COVID-19 vaccine through their local healthcare provider.  If you have an OIB (Croatian Personal Identification Number) and a local health insurance plan, you may visit https://cijepise.zdravlje.hr/ to register to get vaccinated.  If you do not have a local health insurance plan, you may visit the following Croatian Institute of Public Health website for the contact details of the county public health institutes to register by phone.  Visit the FDAâs website to?learn more about FDA-approved vaccines?in the United States.  The United States Government does not plan to provide COVID-19 vaccinations to private U.S. citizens overseas. Please follow host country developments and guidelines for COVID-19 vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211122084519/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

(translated)    Vaccination organization . Vaccination is planned according to the Vaccination Plan.  First it  is planned to vaccinate employees and users of homes for the elderly (and other institutions for the provision of accommodation in the social welfare system) and health professionals, then (conditionally speaking, the  second phase of vaccination ) all persons over 65 and all persons with chronic diseases, and finally (conditionally speaking, the third phase ) the entire population.    The public health institutes will organize the distribution / collection of vaccines in their field, if necessary with the help of the Civil Protection Headquarters (CZ).    Vaccines differ in the method of storage, the method of storage in refrigerators at the place of vaccination and the method of use of the vaccine itself.    The first vaccine to be registered and immediately distributed in the EU Member States is the Pfizer / BioNTech vaccine (trademark Comirnaty), for which the European Medicines Agency on 21.12.2020. gave a positive opinion on the release.    https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-prevenciji/uputa-priprema-za-cijepljenje-protiv-covid-19-884/884

Non-Hungarian nationals may enter the territory of Hungary only in exceptional cases, and exemption to the rules of entry may only be granted by the appropriate police agency at the point of entry into Hungary, or at the 18th District Police Station of the Budapest Police Headquarters upon entry at Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport.    The police agency may authorise entry if the applicant proves that the purpose of entry is:  1. participation in a procedural step of a Hungarian judicial or administrative procedure, proven with an instrument issued by a Hungarian court or authority,  2. receipt of health care with the referral of a health institution or other appropriate proof,  3. a study or examination obligation based on student or pupil status, if proven with a certificate issued by the educational institution,  4. passenger travel related to work associated with forwarding, the purpose of which is travel to the point of departure of the forwarding assignment (location for starting work), or return home by passenger travel after said work, if proven with the certificate issued by the employer,  5. participation in family events (marriage, baptism, funeral),  6. caring for or nursing a relative in accordance with Act V of 2013 of the Civil Code,  7. participation in an international, major religious event, or  8. other equitable grounds.    The passenger may be granted exemption from quarantine, if they present two negative tests in conformity with professional medical regulations within 5 days, with at least 48 hours difference between the tests. In this case, this test shall be considered a first test if it was conducted in a range of countries.    All the rules do not apply if the person is double vaccinated, holds an immunity certificate or has a negative PCR-Test that is not older than 72 hours from a range of countries. Also, the rules do not apply if the person enters the country from a neighbouring country excluding civilian aircrafts.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211217142936/https://visithungary.com/articles/entry-rules-in-force

For residents of Iceland:  Show a certificate of full vaccination , or a certificate of previous infection, at the border. If a certificate is not considered valid, two samples must be taken and a 5-day quarantine in between.  For tourists not from Iceland:  Vaccinated tourists, and those with a confirmed previous infection, must present a negative COVID test before boarding a plane or ship on their way to Iceland. Both the PCR test and the COVID-19 rapid antigen test are accepted. No self-tests are accepted. The test must be taken within 72 hours before departure on the first leg of the trip. If a certificate is not presented at the border, ISK 100,000 is attached. guilt and duty to go to border sampling.  Additionally, if from a high risk area:  Everyone needs to be sampled upon arrival in the country, including children born in 2015 and earlier. Sampling and quarantine: Everyone born in 2015 and earlier must hold a five-day quarantine and go for another sampling at the end of it. Sampling is free. Go directly to the quarantine station from the border station by airport bus, taxi, rental car or private car. You may not be picked up at the airport.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211206181328/https://www.covid.is/undirflokkar/boluefni-eda-motefni  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206181754/https://www.covid.is/undirflokkar/fra-ha-ahaettusvaedi

You quarantine if:  You've been in a relationship with someone who turned out to be infected.  You are traveling abroad and do not have a vaccination certificate or previous COVID-19 infection.  You do not quarantine if:  You've been with someone who was later quarantined.  Your neighbor is infected (for example, in the same stairwell), unless you have been in a lot of contact.  Quarantine ends:  Quarantine can be shortened to 5 days if you go for sampling, otherwise quarantine is 14 days.  You will automatically receive a barcode for the sampling, you do not need to register specifically for it.  A quarantine that takes place in a home where someone is in isolation ends with a negative result from sampling after the isolation has been lifted. Households can then expect a quarantine day longer than isolation lasts. In order to fulfill the conditions for shortening the quarantine to 5 days, there must be a complete separation between the person in isolation and the person in the quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206184014/https://www.covid.is/undirflokkar/sottkvi

Mask duty is indoors, as it is not possible to ensure a 1 meter indoor proximity limit, between individuals who are not in close contact, also at events where guests sit in booked seats. Proximity limits and masks do not apply to children born in 2006 or later.    Face masks should be used indoors where it is not possible to ensure a 1 meter proximity limit such as in health care, shops, museums, domestic flights and ferries, public transport, taxis and group cars, in practical driving and flight training, hairdressing salon activities, beauty salon, beauty salon, massage parlor, massage parlor solarium and other similar activities.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211110102150/https://www.covid.is/undirflokkar/gildandi-takmarkanir

Face masks must be worn wherever the 1 meter social distancing rule cannot be observed between people who are unrelated. Mask obligation does not apply to children born 2006 or later.  Face masks must be used where it is not possible to ensure 1 metre of social distancing, such as in healthcare services, shops, museums, domestic flights and ferries, public transport, taxis and coaches, in practical driving lessons and flight training, hairdressers, beauty salons, massage parlours, tattoo parlours, dog grooming salons, tanning salons and other similar activities.  Those who do not have the understanding or maturity to use a face mask correctly or are unable to do so for other reasons, such as health reasons, do not have to wear a mask.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211220170132/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

no changes in policy, green passes are still required for university students.    Starting September 1st green passes are required for School Personnel only. All students are exempted from this requirement for the time being until and including high school. University students though need to have green passes in order to access the facilities of their university. Universities hence are virtually closed for students without a green pass.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211120012753/https://www.lastampa.it/politica/2021/11/19/news/messa_un_mix_di_lezioni_in_presenza_e_di_dad_cosi_l_universita_vince_la_sfida_del_covid_-433423/  http://web.archive.org/web/20211126180905/https://www.orizzontescuola.it/green-pass-per-studenti-over-12-che-si-recano-a-scuola-con-i-mezzi-pubblici-tanti-i-dubbi/

no changes in policy, green passes are still required for university students.    Starting September 1st green passes are required for School Personnel only. All students are exempted from this requirement for the time being until and including high school. University students though need to have green passes in order to access the facilities of their university. Universities hence are virtually closed for students without a green pass.    Starting Dec 6th a vaccine mandate is in place for all school personnel.   University students still need to hold a green pass to attend lessons in presence.  Some confusion is spreading for all students age 12+ as for people 12+ it is mandatory to hold a green pass for taking public transport, and school transport is not an exception. Ongoing discussions to avoid enforcement of such law for people <18 years old.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211210170128/https://www.wired.it/article/green-pass-scuola-universita-regole-vaccino-mezzi/  http://web.archive.org/web/20211126180905/https://www.orizzontescuola.it/green-pass-per-studenti-over-12-che-si-recano-a-scuola-con-i-mezzi-pubblici-tanti-i-dubbi/  http://web.archive.org/web/20211207075547/https://tg24.sky.it/cronaca/2021/12/07/green-pass-studenti-trasporti

no changes in policy until Dec 6th when new directives will be enforced. Such directives will require green passes for local public transport.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211126180905/https://www.orizzontescuola.it/green-pass-per-studenti-over-12-che-si-recano-a-scuola-con-i-mezzi-pubblici-tanti-i-dubbi/    Previous policy still in place until new directives are formalized:  Green passes are not required for local/short distance transport.  Green passes are required for flights and long-route buses or ferries that are not considered commuter transport.  Long distance transport is only allowed for people with green passes but most means of public transport are still allowed without a green pass, and max capacity is still 80%.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211025183557/https://www.repubblica.it/dossier/cronaca/green-pass/2021/10/13/news/green_pass_quando_e_obbligatorio_dai_ristoranti_ai_trasporti-321936086/

several local red zones in Trentino until Dec 7th  in such zones curfews are in place and no exemptions apply for curfews  Other than the above local red zones, all of Italy is still classified as a white zone except for PA Bolzano and Friuli V.G. which are now classified as yellow zones.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203183904/https://www.qualitytravel.it/colori-regioni-covid-19-le-nuove-zone-rosse-arancioni-gialle-e-bianche-dal-22-marzo/92843  https://web.archive.org/web/20211202211851/https://www.governo.it/it/articolo/domande-frequenti-sulle-misure-adottate-dal-governo/15638

several local red zones in Trentino until Dec 7th, in such zones curfews are in place and no exemptions apply for curfews.  Yellow zones have been established in PA Bolzano and Friuli V.G.. In Yellow zones no curfews are in place.  Other than the above, all of Italy is still classified as a white zone.  A new summary table has been created to clearly explain which activities are possible in every zone from Dec 6th to Jan 15 with or without a Green Pass (negative test, vaccinated or fully recovered) or a Super Green Pass (only vaccinated or fully recovered from Covid): http://web.archive.org/web/20211210171455/https://www.governo.it/sites/governo.it/files/tabella_attivita_consentite_0.pdf    http://web.archive.org/web/20211210171929/https://www.qualitytravel.it/colori-regioni-covid-19-le-nuove-zone-rosse-arancioni-gialle-e-bianche-dal-22-marzo/92843  https://web.archive.org/web/20211208102018/https://www.governo.it/it/articolo/domande-frequenti-sulle-misure-adottate-dal-governo/15638

quote: "Kazakhstan will tighten international entry restrictions from Dec. 3 over concerns regarding the recently identified Omicron variant of COVID-19. From this date, nonresident foreign nationals from the following countries are prohibited from entry: South Africa, Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Madagascar, eSwatini, Malawi, Tanzania, and Hong Kong. Additionally, travelers from countries that have declared the presence of the Omicron variant must - regardless of vaccination status - present a negative PCR test and self-isolate for seven days on arrival; these countries currently include Australia, Belgium, the UK, Czech Republic, Germany, Egypt, Israel, Italy, Canada, and the Netherlands." Still under the 6 month relief programme implemented in July    Quote: "As of early April, 2021, the World Bank has allocated a total of $88 million to aid poor and vulnerable families in the Kyrgyz Republic, and to shield businesses from the economic impacts of the pandemic."  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210618090836/https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/feature/2021/03/17/one-year-later-in-the-kyrgyz-republic-s-battle-against-covid-19    "Nearly half of the project amount ($24 million) will be used to ensure that pensions and other social insurance benefits under the responsibility of the Social Fund are paid in a timely manner for a period of six months.    Moreover, the project will provide assistance through cash benefits and unemployment support.  Up to 200,000 households with approximately 230,000 beneficiary children will receive a monthly child grant for poor families, uy-bulogo komok (UBK).  These new beneficiaries are in addition to the 305,000 existing ones. For a period of six months, the UBK benefit will be topped-up for both existing and new beneficiaries by KGS 300 per month, making it a KGS 1,110 cash allowance per child.        The project will also support up to an estimated 38,000 individuals who have been making regular contributions to the Social Fund but have been laid-off due to the economic crisis precipitated by COVID-19, through financing a monthly unemployment allowance of KGS900 for up to six months."    Archived link:https://web.archive.org/web/20211122175254/https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2020/07/30/kyrgyz-republic-to-mitigate-pandemic-caused-economic-shocks-for-businesses-vulnerable-people-and-communities-with-world-bank-support

No change as per previous update.    Quote: "Key Policy Responses as of June 29, 2021  To mitigate the impact on the economy, the authorities have approved the first package of anti-crisis plan economic measures of $15 million (0.2 percent of GDP) including the postponement of tax payments, time-bound exemptions of property and land taxes, and temporary price controls on 11 essential food items. They prepared a second and a third package of economic measures of about $540 million (7 percent of GDP), including temporary tax exemptions for SMEs, support food security program to the vulnerable groups, and subsidized credit to banks to provide funding to small and medium-size enterprises through soft loans. "  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210712214308/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

COVID-19 Testing    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in the Kyrgyz Republic? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes   The Ministry of Health provides free testing only for symptomatic patients.  For those requiring a negative PCR test for travel, state laboratories in Bishkek and Osh can provide tests for a fee (approximately $20), depending on testing capacity.  Private COVID-19 testing is also available for a fee ($30) at Bonetsky Laboratory or Aqualab.  Please contact the laboratory directly to inquire about their testing capacity.  All four labs deliver results via email and include a QR-code to verify the authenticity of the test results.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211211163959/https://kg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

COVID-19 Vaccine Information:    Has the government of the Kyrgyz Republic approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes  Are vaccines available in the Kyrgyz Republic for U.S. citizens to receive? Yes  Which vaccines are available in the Kyrgyz Republic?   Sinopharm, Sputnik V, AstraZeneca, and a limited supply of Pfizer (see below)  According to Kyrgyz Republic authorities, Sinopharm, Sputnik V, and AstraZeneca vaccines are now available at government clinics for all those who wish to receive it. An online vaccination appointment can be made here: https://vc.emed.gov.kg  According to the Ministry of Health, as of October 30, 2021, the Pfizer vaccine will be available at all temporary vaccination points in Bishkek and three points in the Chui Oblast: in Alamedin, Sokuluk Districts and in the city of Kant. From November 1, the vaccine will be gradually delivered to all regions of the country. Pfizer vaccine will be given to anyone over the age of 18.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211211163959/https://kg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

In addition to current measures, until 14 January 2022 inclusive, additional sanitary measures are applicable to all travel from Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Zimbabwe. Upon arrival in the Grand Duchy, the persons concerned are placed in strict quarantine for 7 days with the obligation to undergo a second nucleic acid amplification tests of SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA (PCR, TMA or LAMP methods) from the 6th day of quarantine. In the event of refusal to submit to the test on arrival or at the end of the 7-day quarantine period, the quarantine will be extended for a further 7 days, bringing the total duration to 14 days. https://archive.ph/Yg0rU

Kindergartens operate as usually. In primary and secondary education and universities the study process takes place in person, in strict compliance with general safety measures. Pupils at school take a routine screening test, while all students must be vaccinated. The staff that works at education institutions must be vaccinated.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211204205121/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

The study process takes place in person, in strict compliance with general safety measures. Only students with Covid-19 certificates can attend classes, other must study online.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211220083909/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

In private sector from 15 December 2021, all employees working on-site (or outside their place of residence) must present a Covid-19 vaccination or recovery certificate. In public sector From 15 December 2021, all employees must present a Covid-19 vaccination or recovery certificate, regardless of how they perform their duties, remotely or on-site.  On-site work is allowed with the order of the employer to ensure the continuity of work if it cannot be performed remotely. Shops, restaurants and services are open with no limitation, but only until 9PM and only for vaccinated people.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211204205121/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

PE classes are held in accordance with current health measures  Masks must be worn during sports activities  School swimming lessons are suspended  http://web.archive.org/web/20211221134119/https://covid19.mc/en/the-sanitary-measures-in-force/

Everyone will have to show their health pass to drink inside and on the terraces of restaurants and bars. This also applies to young people aged 16 to 18   The health pass will also be required for access to theatres and congresses when there are more than 300 people.  Booking is required in restaurants and there is maximum of 12 people per table (seated service)  There must be a distance between tables in restaurants of at least 1 metre on the terrace and inside  For customers, wearing a mask will be required in the queue. However, it will no longer be compulsory inside the establishment  Standing consumption is not allowed  In sports halls, auditoriums or congress halls, the public capacity is increased from 70% to 100% of the seats, an exemption being possible on presentation of a specific health protocol  http://web.archive.org/web/20211221134119/https://covid19.mc/en/the-sanitary-measures-in-force/

It is no longer limited to 10 people. However, it is strongly recommended to observe the barrier gestures.Restrictions on capacity, masks and Covid pass required  http://web.archive.org/web/20211221134119/https://covid19.mc/en/the-sanitary-measures-in-force/

The Government has set up a National Screening Center. It is located on the ground floor of the Rainier III Auditorium. The Government of Monaco is proposing a "3rd dose" to Monegasques and residents aged 65 and over as well as health professionals provided that they have received the last dose of vaccine against Covid-19 more than six months ago. Moldova has banned entry to foreigners who were physically present in the last 14 days in South Africa, Lesotho, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Namibia, Eswatini, or Malawi.  For travellers from other countries, Moldova requires that they present one of the following:  1) a negative PCR COVID-19 test (taken in the last 72 hours) or an antigen test (taken in the last 48 hours); 2) a COVID-19 vaccine certificate (valid 14 days after the second dose; all types accepted); 3) a medical certificate attesting the person had COVID-19 in the previous 6 months; 4) a COVID-19 antibodies certificate valid for 90 days from the exam date.  Any COVID-19 antibodies certificate or evidence of vaccination must be in Romanian, English, French, German, Italian, or Russian language.    People who cannot provide one of the four options above must self-isolate for 14 days, with a negative PCR test result on day 7 sufficient to end isolation.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211208231759/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
